title: ARTH 322: Early Modern Italian Art and Culture (ca. 1550-1700)
description: This website is for the course ARTH 322 Early Modern Italian Art and Culture (ca. 1550-1700): The Spectacle fo the Counter Reformation taught by Joseph Monteyne in the Department of Art History, Visual Art and Theory, University of British Columbia. This course provides a study of the visual culture of Counter Reformation Italy, with particular emphasis on Rome as the center of artistic, cultural, economic, and religious life in seventeenth century Italy.
subject: Art; Italian culture
creator: Joseph Monteyne; UBC AHVA Visual Resources Centre

title: ARTH 320: Entangled Worlds
description: This website is for the course ARTH 320 Entangled Worlds: Art and Architecture in Spain and Colonial Latin America taught by Joseph Monteyne in the Department of Art History, Visual Art and Theory, University of British Columbia. This course surveys painting, sculpture, and architecture in Spain and colonial Latin America during the reign of the Habsburg dynasty with a focus on transcultural modes.
subject: Art; Architecture
creator: Joseph Monteyne; UBC AHVA Visual Resources Centre

title: Tacoma Japanese Language School Oral History Collection
description: Oral histories from Tacoma's Nisei community about the Japanese Language School and their lives in pre-war Puget Sound.
subject: Japanese; Washington
creator: Erika Bailey; University of Washington Tacoma Library

title: Runakunaq Bibliotecanku
description: Runakunaq Bibliotecanku is a collection of Quechua and Andean-centered materials.
subject: Andean studies; Magazines; Poetry
creator: Alia Warsco; Center for Latin American and Caribbean Studies at NYU

title: Meridian Police Department Collection
description: This is a digital collection of historical documents pertaining to the Meridian, Idaho Police Department
subject: Police; Local history; Idaho
creator: Meridian Library District History Center

title: Meridian Library District Digital Collections
description: Since 2022, the Meridian Library District has been digitizing Meridian historical collections in an effort to preserve, document, and make available the history and culture of the area. You can browse the library's digital collections using this platform.
subject: Local history; Idaho
creator: Meridian Library District History Center

title: The Oregon Forestry Industry
description: Created by students in LIB 410: Humanities Research Data Management at the University of Oregon, this digital collection thematic research topic is focused on the forestry industry in Oregon in the 19th and 20th centuries. The students chose this topic because forestry is an important part of Oregon’s history and economy, as the state is still one of the top producers of lumber in the United States today. This collection focuses on the workers who help run this industry, with photographs depicting men at work, maps of worker camp sites, as well as the tools and machinery they used to process and transport lumber collected from different GLAMS. By collecting these digital objects together, the students hope that viewers can get a glimpse into the day-to-day lives of loggers and forestry workers in Oregon.
subject: Forestry; Logging
creator: Isabelle Dana; Mattie Lucero; Elena Perez; Cecelia Staggs

title: Haunted Locations in Oregon
description: Created by students in LIB 410: Humanities Research Data Management at the University of Oregon, this digital collection is a survey of reportedly haunted locations in Oregon, mostly consisting of photographs of historic buildings and cemeteries. The collection consists of 21 images taken from 1855 to 1977 in several regions of Oregon, including the Willamette Valley, the coast, and Southern Oregon. Locations were designated haunted by personal recollection of folk legends as well as by other Oregonians. Objects were collected through a combination of national and state repositories. The collection offers a different look at a survey of historical places in Oregon by taking into account Oregon’s long history of superstition and folk legends.
subject: Historic houses; Hotels; Haunted locations
creator: Emily Colson; Olivia Wilkinson; Jonathan Nelson; Matt Skeels

title: Asian Heritage in Oregon Throughout History
description: Created by students in LIB 410: Humanities Research Data Management at the University of Oregon, this digital collection focuses on the immigration of Asian populations to Oregon from 1850-1980, with a focus on primary sources to help narrate the important and complex story of Asian immigration during a century of turmoil for these communities in America. We are including photographs, letters, art, artifacts, legal documents, newspaper articles, and more to formulate a thematic and chronological history of these diverse communities within Oregon.
subject: Immigration; Chinese Americans; Chinese
creator: Claire Matucan; Regan Robinson; Jackson Scharf; Daveena Williams

title: Women and Healing in US History, 1600-1865
description: A series of manuals, books, journal and newspaper articles, photographs, prints, and lectures on the history and practices of midwives and female physicians, between roughly 1700 and 1865. This collection was generated for the class, US Women's History to 1865, created and taught by Susan Pearson, and was made possible by the Chabraja Center for Historical Studies at Northwestern University.
subject: Midwives; Newspapers; Women physicians
creator: Susan Pearson; Emily Lyon

title: Mayes Gray Collection
description: The Mayes Gray Collection (Meridian, Idaho) extends from the early 1900's through 1940
subject: Local history; Family history; Idaho
creator: Meridian Library District History Center

title: Girl Graduate - Her Own Book
description: Ardath Lillian Caldwell was a graduate of Meridian High School - Class of 1922
subject: Scrapbooks; Local history; Idaho
creator: Meridian Library District History Center

title: Meridian Occident Club
description: The Occident Club was a community service organization serving Meridian, Idaho from 1924-1996.
subject: Public libraries; Local history; Idaho
creator: Meridian Library District History Center

title: Dairy Days
description: The annual Dairy Days show celebrates Meridian's rich history as a dairy town.
subject: Parades; Community events; Local history; Idaho
creator: Meridian Library District History Center

title: The Black Press
description: A collection of 24 digitized images of African American publications (magazines, journals, newspapers) from the early-to-mid twentieth century to highlight, contextualize, and commemorate the political and creative significance of these resources and how they altogether served as a counter-endeavor to the past dehumanizing strategy of forced illiteracy from the period of enslavement in the United States, a space to highlight the unique and singular creative expressions of African Americans, and an earnest pursuit to speak to new generations of African Americans, (and all interested parties beyond the African American community) across class stratification whose political consciousness was increasing as civil liberties were continually challenged by oppressive socio-political structures.
subject: African americans; Newspapers
creator: MarQuis Bullock

title: McCall Public Library Collection
description: The McCall Public Library Collection is a digital collection of local family history and subjects of interest. The documents were collected by the McCall Public Library and the Payette Lakes Progressive Club for over a half-century. This extensive collection of unique transcribed oral histories, obituaries, articles and photos filled up several filing cabinets in the Library.
subject: Local history; Family history; Idaho
creator: University of Idaho Library; McCall Public Library; Payette Lakes Progressive Club

title: La Revolución a color
description: Imágenes del porfiriato y la Revolución mexicana a color. Fotografías provenientes de diferentes archivos.
subject: Mexican history; Mexican Revolution
creator: Ignacio Emerio Anaya Minjarez

title: Memoria Sonora de Bogotá
description: Bienvenidos al archivo digital 'Memoria Sonora de Bogota: Teusaquillo y Chapinero en las décadas de 1960 y 1970'. Esta colección de historias orales, recoge las memorias sonoras de habitantes de las dos localidades en archivos mp3 con el fin de utilizarlas para investigaciones sobre la historia y cultura de Bogotá. La investigación presentada hace parte del proyecto de grado “Memoria sonora de Bogotá: la importancia del sonido en nuestra relación afectiva con los lugares”, presentado en la Maestría de Humanidades Digitales de la Universidad de Los Andes en noviembre de 2021.
subject: Radio; Music
creator: Liliana París Borda

title: Edificati sulla parola
description: Urban Center di Monza, 14-28 febbraio 2011, con il patrocinio di Ambasciata della Repubblica d'Armenia in Italia e con la collaborazione della Congregazione Mechitarista del Monastero di San Lazzaro, Venezia
creator: Antonella Fabbri

title: 19th Century Stereo Cards of St. Catharines
description: These stereo cards were acquired in February with the intention to make these publicly available.
subject: Local history; Stereo cards; Photographs
creator: David Sharron; Brock University Archives

title: Geodata Listing
description: This collection includes information about a variety of geospatial data sources available to the Brock University community for use with GIS software.
subject: Geospatial data; Satellite imagery; Topographic maps
creator: Sharon Janzen; Digital Scholarship Lab at Brock University Library

title: Granite Mountain Hotshots Tribute Fence
description: This collection contains video, textual, and image files from the Tribute Fence Preservation Project from Prescott Public Library. Items were left to honor the memory of the Granite Mountain Hotshots between June 30 and September 10, 2013.
subject: Firefighters; Local history
creator: ruhrose

title: KIBO: Commission on Human Rights Digital Archive
description: KIBO is the Commission on Human Rights of the Philippines (CHRP) Digital Archive. It is a repository of CHRP’s collections of digital assets such as video, images, audio files, among others with the intention of providing long-term access to information with varying evidential, legal, or contextual value. The word ‘kibo’ comes from the shortened version of the Filipino translation of archive ‘arkibo’. It also means ‘movement’ or ‘action’ in Filipino and translates to ‘hope’ in Japanese. The three meanings of the term aptly describe the vision of the digital archive project: to preserve memory while inciting action and hope.
subject: Human rights; International humanitarian law
institution: Commission on Human Rights of the Philippines (CHRP)
creator: Apple Lyn Davalos; Paul Jason Perez; Allan Jay Monteclaro

title: Idaho Queered
description: Idaho Queered is a collection of LGBTQ+ Oral Histories that were recorded during 2017-2018. Featuring interviews with queer Idahoans that detail their experiences with coming out, fighting discrimination, and navigating the particular challenges of their lives, the project aims to help preserve LGBTQ history through audio and video storytelling.
subject: LGBTQ; Idaho; Interviews
institution: TheCDIL, Center for Digital Inquiry and Learning, University of Idaho Library
creator: TheCDIL, Center for Digital Inquiry and Learning, University of Idaho Library

title: Founding Stories
description: UW Tacoma Oral History: Founding Stories is a collection of first-hand accounts from the students, faculty, staff, and community members who played significant roles in establishing and shaping UW Tacoma. This collection website is built on CollectionBuilder-CONTENTdm.
subject: University history
creator: UWTacomaLibrary, University of Washington Libraries Digital Collections

title: She Changed the World
description: This collection includes previously digitized state publications, photographs, letters, oral histories, posters, and other materials related to women's history in North Carolina.
subject: North Carolina; Women's history
institution: State Library of North Carolina; State Archives of North Carolina
creator: North Carolina Digital Collections

title: eXOspACES
description: An album/series of imperfect/poor image/low-resolution abstractions based on smartphone screen captures of Jonathan Matteson's gameplay in the retro jet fighter genre to celebrate/perpetuate the Neon Noir dystopian sci-fi aesthetic during the dawn of deep space discoveries, drone warfare, and ESports. Published to the internet as social media content to encourage reflection in reflexive times as an introspective aesthetic experience by a visual musician who wants to see additive algorithms outlawed.
subject: Digital art; Screen captures
creator: Jonathan S. Matteson

title: Butte Stope Books
description: The mines in Butte, Montana, rich in base and precious metals, began to take shape in the 1870s and continued through 1982 when the underground mining was shut down. Mapping and surveying the geology, mineralogy, and mine workings of 100+ mines became the responsibility of the ACM Geology Department. The underground mine openings are generally referred to as stopes; detailed maps of the stopes were recorded from field books to a master Stope Book for each mine. This collection of books was the responsibility of the Anaconda Mining Company (founded in 1881) and is a hand-drawn representation of the tens of thousands of miles of underground workings that make up what is known worldwide as the “Richest Hill on Earth.”
subject: Mines; Montana; Stopes; Geology; Maps
institution: Montana Bureau of Mines and Geology
creator: Chelsea Pincock

title: Aswang sa Aklatan
description: The Philippine government, through the regional bodies of its National Task Force to End Local Communist Armed Conflict (NTF-ELCAC) and the Commission on Higher Education, is asking librarians to pull “subversive” and “mentally unhealthy” books from their collections. This collection asserts that libraries are safe spaces for learning and that every book is a chance to freely and critically encounter ideas. Created by Academics Unite for Democracy and Human Rights, an alliance of Filipino teachers, researchers, school administrators, and other education professionals who stand for democratic rights and freedom in the academe and beyond.
subject: Libraries; Book banning
institution: Academics Unite for Democracy and Human Rights
creator: Paul Jason Perez

title: Lost Tacoma
description: This collection is a partial representation of the Tacoma Public Library Northwest Room's Lost Tacoma collection, constituting 116 of the total 560 blueprints across 28 locations. Technical drawings include both proposed buildings which were never constructed and constructed buildings which are now demolished.
subject: Blueprints; Buildiings
creator: Andrew Weymouth

title: Global Medieval and Early Modern Digital Library (GMEMS)
description: The Global Medieval and Early Modern Digital Library brings together translations, often accompanied by transcriptions, of primary sources encompassing a wide range of genres, regions and languages from the period between Late Antiquity and 1700. The site allows these sources to be organized by theme, region, language and date.
subject: Medieval texts; Translations
creator: upenndigitalscholarship

title: Victorian Jewish Writers Project
description: The Victorian Jewish Writers Project is an archive dedicated to the study of Judaism in nineteenth-century Britain. Jews have played a prominent part in British history and culture, a fact that is too often ignored both in scholarship on Britain and in scholarship on Jews and Judaism. Despite being overlooked by scholars, British Jews were extremely prolific writers, leaving behind a treasury of literary materials showcasing their lives, interests, and concerns. Thanks to the pioneering efforts of researchers who have scoured archives and museums in order to publish books and articles, authors like Zangwill and Aguilar are increasingly becoming known to scholars and students of the nineteenth century. VJWP makes these authors accessible once more to anyone with an interest in Anglo-Jewry.
subject: Victorian era; Literature; Jewish literature; Writing
creator: Lindsay Katzir; Brandon Katzir

title: Environmental Justice Research Repository
description: This digital collection was created in partnership between the University of Oregon's ENG 470 Technologies & Texts Capstone course and the UO Libraries DREAM Lab, and in consultation with Beyond Toxics, a nonprofit organization working for environmental justice in Oregon. It serves as a repository of research materials related to the history of environmental racism in the Eugene-Springfield community.
subject: Environmental justice; Racism; Environmental activism; Urban ecology
creator: Kate Thornhill; Mattie Burkert

title: Victorian Visual Culture
description: An exhibition on Victorian Visual Culture. Curated and created by students in VISA 2P90 at Brock University.
subject: Victorian era; Victorian art; Victorian culture
creator: J. Keri Cronin

title: Local Gems from the Farmington Room
description: A collection of images of select items held in the Farmington Libraries' local history room, called the Farmington Room
subject: Local history; Scrapbooks
creator: FarmingtonLibraries

title: Mathematicians of the 20th Century
description: The purpose of this website is to display biographical entries of influential mathematicians born in the first half of the 20th century. It provides short descriptions for the contributions of the mathematicians, their birthplaces, their birthdates, and images for identification. The website is created for educational purposes, for the class of Sir Daryl Saddi, Math 10.
subject: Mathematicians; Biographies
creator: Eugeryl Paul Rondario

title: Mapping Makerspaces
description: This project maps makerspaces in public libraries in southern Ontario. Browse the map and corresponding word clouds to find makerspaces of all sorts, the tools, equipment and spaces available, their branch locations, and more. Under Resources, find readings, programs, and project ideas to put in place at your local makerspace.
subject: Makerspaces; Public libraries; Mapping
collection_type: Course; Mapping Project; Digital Scholarship Project
creator: Tegan Emes; Adrienne Orr

title: Objects of Empire
description: This collection of airline menus was created to help teach the course Objects of Empire. It is meant to serve as a sample for the development of future digital collections.
subject: Airline menus; Airlines
institution: Northwestern University; Chabraja Center for Historical Studies
creator: Emily Lyon

title: Tracing Welty
description: This collection explores Eudora Welty's connections to the Natchez Trace. Between 1940 and 1943, Welty set several stories and a novella along the Natchez Trace. She also wrote about this historic roadway in her 1944 essay, 'Some Notes on River Country.' Taking a cue from Digital Yoknapatawpha and like projects, Tracing Welty maps Welty's references to the Trace and uses historical materials to place them in different interpretive contexts.
subject: Literature; Eudora Welty; Mapping
creator: Michael Pickard Syner; Patricia Seraiah Lodge

title: puzzleswap
description: Puzzleswap includes image files of 21 puzzles, either in boxes or completed, ready to swapped to new puzzlers. Most puzzles are created with recycled paper or cardboard, and they feature a range between 500 to 1,000 pieces.
subject: Puzzles
creator: Amanda Epperson

title: Digital Videogame Art Scan Project
description: This project is a collection of box art, instruction manuals, cartridges, and discs from a personal video game collection. It features materials from the Sega Genesis, Sega Dreamcast, Nintendo GameCube, and Nintendo DS. Each game also features a link to YouTube videos that show trailers or examples of gameplay from particular titles and even the chance to play some titles through the Internet Archive’s use of web-based emulation. Created as part of the Z652 Digital Libraries course at Indiana University.
subject: Video games; Video game art
creator: John Knight

title: To the Happy Couple
description: A collection of materials from the bridal shower and wedding of Suzanne Stratman and Harry Machenheimer. Created as part of the Z652 Digital Libraries course at Indiana University.
subject: Marriage; Wedding photographs; Wedding cards
creator: Casey Machenheimer

title: Knit Stitch Library
description: The Knit Stitch Library is a collection for knitters interested in getting information on several different kinds of knitting stitches. It is a resource for everyone interested in knitting, whether they are just starting out or are more advanced and looking for inspiration. All stitches shown have detailed instructions, pattern abbreviations, difficulty ratings, ways to use this stitch, as well as information about the origin of the stitch if known. Created as part of the Z652 Digital Libraries course at Indiana University.
subject: Knitting; Arts and crafts
creator: Brandis Malone

title: Concert Programs of Pieces by Kathryn Edom
description: A digital collection of programs for concerts featuring pieces composed by Kathryn Edom. Created as part of the Z652 Digital Libraries course at Indiana University.
subject: Music; Concerts
creator: Kathryn Edom

title: Status and the Sacred
description: This site is intended to serve as a resource for information about books of hours and certain information about Medieval Western European life associated with them. It is primarily designed to serve as a repository for scans of a book of hours in the collection of the Lilly Library at Indiana University Bloomington.
subject: Religion; Medieval texts; Medieval Europe
creator: Alan Morris

title: The Art of Tarot
description: This is a digital image collection sampling cards from multiple Tarot decks. The purpose of this collection is to show how different artists, separated by time, gender, and culture, each interprets the centuries-old format of Tarot. Created as part of the Z652 Digital Libraries course at Indiana University.
subject: Tarot; Art; Spiritualism
creator: Julia Parkinson

title: Reed Cats
description: The two cats of the house of Reed, Lulu and Pan and all their activities. Created as part of a class on on GitHub and Git.
subject: Cats; Pets
creator: Kayla Reed

title: Clement Wragge: A Selection of Items from Trove
description: This exhibition was generated from a Trove List by the GLAM Workbench. The notebook converts Trove lists into a series of files that can be uploaded to a CollectionBuilder-GH repository to create an instant exhibition.
subject: Meteorology; Meteorologist
creator: Tim Sherratt

title: Coins of the Cairo Geniza
description: This is a digital paleographical glossary for dating textual fragments. This resource can assist researchers in dating geniza fragments that do not explicitly mention years of recording but instead retain numismatic data. In many instances, the production history of coinage can aid us in estimating the earliest year in which a text may have been recorded.
subject: Coins; Palaeography
creator: Matthew Dudley; Alan Elbaum

title: Mapping Lifta
description: This project documents the remnants of Palestinian Lifta.
subject: Lifta; Palestine
creator: Jeff O'Brien

title: Chocolates Juncosa
description: Collection of 36 chromo trade cards produced by Spanish company Chocolates E. Juncosa. The cards depict the Cuban War of Independence (1895-1898) and the beginning of the Spanish-American War.
subject: Cigar labels; Chromo trade cards; Cuban War of Independence
institution: The University of Texas at Austin
creator: Lauren Peña

title: Charley Harper and the National Park Service
description: This image gallery presents a portion of Harper’s commissioned work by the U.S. National Park Service and related maps. Prints of these works in poster format as well as the maps which relate to the geographic areas represented in Harper’s artwork are owned by the University of Kentucky Libraries and have been digitized by the UK Libraries’ Special Collections and Research Center.
subject: Art; Posters; National Park Service
creator: Jennifer Hootman

title: Muskuy Yachay Archives
description: This collection contains materials related to Kichwa-language muskuy narratives of the Runa of Ecuador. It includes audiovisual, textual, and image files from the Lisa W. Carney's doctoral dissertation 'By the Authority of Dreams Truth and Knowledge in Kichwa Muskuy Narratives.'
subject: Pottery; Indigenous knowledge
creator: Lisa W. Carney

title: Mineral and Rock Collection
description: This is a mineral and rock collection gathered from Travis Jackson's personal collection with a variety of specimens presented in their polished and rough forms.
subject: Rocks; Minerals
creator: Irene Lewis

title: The Boldest 19th Century Dare Devils
description: This is a digital collection of images detailing 19th century Dare Devils tightroping and barreling over the Falls. The three main individuals chosen are Annie Edson Taylor, Henry Bellini, and Charles Blondin. Created as part of the VISA 2P90: 19th Century Visual Culture course at Brock University.
subject: Tightroping; Visual culture
creator: Luana Amatuzio

title: Urban Family Recipe Collection
description: This recipe collection began its life in a three-ring yellow binder which initially served as a way to preserve beloved family recipes for family members to reference and recreate. The Urban Family Recipe Collection is a digital repository that collects many of these recipes. Organized by a variety of means, including a recipe’s creator, main ingredient, seasonality of ingredients, cooking method, or meal type, there are many ways to locate a desired recipe. Once found, recipes can easily be printed or downloaded as a PDF for ease of reference or annotation. This collection will hopefully continue to grow as new recipes are developed.
subject: Recipes; Family history
creator: Katie Mikulka

title: La Rana: PCTO Liceo Galvani e Università di Bologna
description: Il progetto intende attivare la ricerca, archiviazione, digitalizzazione, metadatazione e creazione di una Digital library del giornalino scolastico La Rana, pubblicato dal 1961 al 1968 e conservato parzialmente nell'Archivio Storico del Galvani, ma implementabile nella collezione completa con copie provenienti dalla Biblioteca Universitaria di Bologna e dall'Archivio della biblioteca stessa.
subject: Newspapers
creator: Anna Sofia Lippolis

title: The Wonders of Ifugao
description: A collection of digital resources citing Ifugao culture. The Ifugao inhabit the most rugged mountainous part of the Philippines, high up in the central Cordillera in northern Luzon. The area refused to submit to numerous colonizers and thus preserve its rich cultural diversity.
subject: Ifugao; Cultural diversity
creator: 2X9 Group

title: Sinapupunan: Celebrating the Best of Filipina Directors
description: Sinapupunan is a digital exhibit compiling and celebrating the best films and documentaries of Filipina directors in the 21st century.
subject: Film; Film directors
creator: Anton Campos; Dan Gabriel Castro; Nadine Coronel; Gail Daniel; Mark Andy Pedere

title: UP LISSA Memoirs
description: This collection aims to commemorate and promote University of the Philippines Library and Information Science Students Association (UP LISSA). With UP LISSA’s long and colorful history, let us all look back and celebrate UP LISSA’s events throughout the years, as well as its members’ accomplishments. Created as part of the CWTS 2 SLIS - Strengthening of a Barangay Library course at the University of the Philippines.
subject: Student organizations; Library Science
creator: Khaye Cee A. Benedicto; Joseph Emmanuel S. Chan; Dominique De Guzman; Ralph Anthon Dela Torre; Rad Julongbayan

title: Rizal Hall@100
description: This collection contains images of Rizal Hall at the University of the Philippines throughout history. Every academic year, hundreds of freshies climb up the historic stairs of Rizal Hall to attend their General Education (GE) subjects in the College of Arts and Sciences (CAS).
subject: University history; University buildings
creator: Mary Dorothy dL. Jose; Paul Jason Perez

title: Gertzel Library
description: This collection provides a broad overview of the published material from the library of the late Africanist scholar Prof. Cherry Gertzel (http://cherrygertzel.net). It shows the subject areas, as well as the quantity and types, of published material in the Gertzel Library. The purpose of the collection is to make information about it more readily available in order to find a suitable home (or homes) for the material so that it can be used by Africanist scholars and researchers.
subject: Africanist scholarship
creator: Karen Miller

title: Heaven and Earth
description: This collection focuses on painting, sculpture, and graphic art in France, the Netherlands, Germany, and England in the 15th and 16th centuries, with special emphasis on the major figures of this period, from van Eyck and van der Weyden to Grunewald, Bosch, Durer, Holbein, and Pieter Bruegel. This site is meant to showcase content covered in the ARTH 323 Heaven and Earth: Renaissance Art and Culture in Northern Europe 1400-1600 course at the University of British Columbia.
subject: Renaissance; European art; Art
creator: Joseph Monteyne; UBC AHVA Visual Resources Centre

title: And They Called It Vancouver
description: This digital exhibition features photographs and postcards from the Uno Langmann Family Collection of B.C. Photographs, housed at UBC's Rare Books and Special Collections.
subject: Postcards; Local history; Family history
creator: Ashlynn Prasad

title: Middle East and North Africa Illustrated
description: Middle East and North Africa Illustrated (MENAI) is an annually updated database of bibliographical information on all graphic novels that are related to the Middle Eastern and North African countries in various genres that are written in or translated into English. The MENAI is a side product of the HONORS 212 Near/Middle East Illustrated course at the University of Washington.
subject: Graphic novels; Middle East; North Africa
creator: Selim S. Kuru; Andrew Weymouth

title: Beaverhead Mine Documents
description: This collection contains mining documents for properties and claims within Beaverhead County in southwest Montana. These documents include assays, correspondence, maps, news clippings, photos, publications, reports, surveys, or other material related to any property.
subject: Mines; Montana; Maps; Mining documents
institution: Montana Bureau of Mines and Geology
creator: Montana Bureau of Mines and Geology

title: Lloyd C. Furer Cross Sections
description: After 20 years in the oil industry, Lloyd Furer joined Indiana University and, among other research activities, taught surface geology for 10 years at the Indiana field station near Cardwell, Montana. Since retiring, Lloyd has spent decades correlating subsurface formations in the western U.S. based on his knowledge of surface geology and thousands of geophysical logs from Montana, Wyoming, Colorado, and the Dakotas. This collection of over 50 cross sections represents a portion of Lloyd Furer’s correlation work in Montana.
subject: Geology; Montana; Geological cross-sections
institution: Montana Bureau of Mines and Geology
creator: Montana Bureau of Mines and Geology

title: A Shaky Truce
description: This digital oral and public history project was a cooperative effort to showcase the unique history of Starkville, Mississippi’s civil rights struggles with particular emphasis on the local fight for school desegregation. This website is designed to tell a story of local activism and provide information for scholars and tools for teachers interested in exploring these local conversations about race, equality, and human rights.
subject: Civil rights movements; Desegregation; Activism
institution: Mississippi University for Women; University of Colorado
creator: Deep South DH

title: The Smith Papers Collection
description: The Smith Family Papers includes letters and diaries among family members and friends, with most letters from members of the Smith Family--Pauline and Sam H, and their children, Bernice, Christine, Martha, and “Sonny Boy.”
subject: Letters; Diaries; Family history
creator: MUW Digital Studies

title: Postcards from the Global South
description: Postcards from the Global South uses picture postcards to document colonial visual discourses on Mexico during the regime of Porfirio Díaz, and Korea during the first decades of the Japanese Occupation.
subject: Korea--Japanese Occupation; Postcards
creator: Cal Poly Pomona

title: W.K. Kellogg Arabian Horse Library Postcard and Notecard Collection
description: The W.K. Kellogg Arabian Horse Library Postcard and Notecard Collection spans from the 1920s to the 1970s and contains both postcards and notecards with a connection to either the W.K. Kellogg Arabian Horse Ranch in Pomona, California or the Kellogg Company in Battle Creek, Michigan. The postcards mostly depict horses of the Kellogg Ranch but there are also scenic views of the property and Kellogg House, as well as various locations of the Kellogg Company.
subject: Postcards; Horse ranches
creator: Cal Poly Pomona; W.K. Kellogg Arabian Horse Library

title: Colors of Ozu
description: This is an ongoing, film analysis and digital scholarship project examining the color films of Japanese filmmaker Yasujirō Ozu (1903-1963). The project leverages digital tools and technologies to novelly and creatively examine Ozu's final six films.
subject: Color films; Film directors
creator: Dave Rodriguez

title: Performance and Exploitation
description: This digital archive is comprised of people with dwarfism, as well as a few who had giantism. This project's purpose is to ask how the gaze, in its passing between staring and attention, can be interrogated to reveal the prejudices which still single out the anomalously bodied for the simple reason that they appear different from the normally bodied in their own ways of living.
subject: Physical disabilities; Circuses; Performance art
creator: New College of Florida

title: Beauty in Variation
description: This collection examines "beauty" displayed in Ringling Circus's archives. A circus act tells us what bodies and visual traits were stigmatized and considered abnormal in the time and place of their performance. This allows us to draw conclusions about the definition of "normal" and about standards of beauty within the setting we're observing. In this collection, the visuals shown are forms of beauty modifications such as, but not limited to, clothing, accessories, extra limbs, and hair.
subject: Beauty; Circuses
creator: New College of Florida

title: Pain and Performace
description: This collection is organized around core themes of pain and performance, as they are deployed across four categories common to circus "freak shows": swords and sword swallowing, needles and nails, extreme strength, and performers inflicting pain on another. In each case, the performers' ability to complete these feats inspires an awe that may override sympathy. While circus freak shows often featured performers and bodies that were visibly physically disabled, we call the subjects of this collection "overly-abled," in order to highlight their difference but still call attention to the similar ways in which they are dehumanized.
subject: Circuses; Pain
creator: New College of Florida

title: Football in America
description: This site features select football-related collections from the University of Notre Dame Archives. Metadata was generated as part of Prof. Katherine Walden's F21 "Football In America" course.
subject: Football
creator: Katherine Walden

title: Willett Family Photo Album
description: The Willett family traveled from Bridgewater, Massachusetts to Meridian, Idaho in 1921 to visit their daughter. This photograph collection documents their six-week cross-country journey in an auto bungalow.
subject: Local history; Scrapbooks; Idaho
creator: Meridian Library District History Center

title: Wyoming Oral History Online
description: Wyoming is rich in oral history: an estimated 5,000 oral history interviews are archived in nearly 50 museums, libraries, and other institutions around the state. The Wyoming Oral History Online database (WOHO) contains more than 3500 oral histories from across Wyoming. The Wyoming State Historical Society created this database to make these materials easy for researchers to find.
subject: Interviews; Wyoming
creator: Wyoming State Historical Society

title: We Exist Series 5
description: We Exist is an ongoing six-part series looking at the history of Maine’s African American communities, curated by Dr. Lance Gibbs from the University of Southern Maine. This is the 5th installment, entitled "Stories of African American Education and Employment in Maine," which examines where African Americans have learned and worked.
subject: Maine; Local history; African Americans
creator: Paul Fuller; Lance Gibbs; Mary Holt

title: Storying Extinction
description: Storying Extinction is a multidisciplinary digital humanities project that represents community response to the recent extirpation (2019) of southern mountain caribou from the South Selkirk mountains of North Idaho—the last caribou to inhabit the coterminous United States.
subject: Extinction; Mapping; Caribou; Idaho
institution: TheCDIL, Center for Digital Inquiry and Learning, University of Idaho Library
creator: TheCDIL, Center for Digital Inquiry and Learning, University of Idaho Library

title: Modernizing the Landscape
description: This exhibition is a collection of images and texts that explore how Niagara's booming industry in the 19th century visually changed, collaborated with, or overwhelmed the landscape around it. The collection explores the visual culture of 19th century Niagara that displayed the relationship between factory and nature, and presented industry as an embedded, inexorable feature of Niagara’s environment. Created as part of the VISA 2P90: 19th Century Visual Culture course at Brock University.
subject: Niagara Falls; Industrialization; Niagara Region
creator: Madeline Collins

title: Exploring the Influence of Wine in 19th Century Niagara
description: This collection displays resources sourced from the Brock Archives and Special Collections regarding wine and grape growing in the Niagara region from the 19th century. Placing these images within a larger context within the 19th century, we see the influx of new technology influencing the industrialization of the wine industry across the wide scale Niagara region in Ontario. Created as part of the VISA 2P90: 19th Century Visual Culture course at Brock University.
subject: Niagara Falls; Wine; Niagara Region
creator: Sarah Puckett

title: Hydroelectric Power at Niagara Falls
description: An exhibition on the relationship of hydroelectricity with Niagara Falls. The images in this exhibition aim to tell the story of the construction of the Niagara Parks Power Station and how the infrastructure looks today. Created as part of the VISA 2P90: 19th Century Visual Culture course at Brock University.
subject: Hydroelectric power; Niagara Falls; Niagara Region
creator: Ella Sexton

title: The Honeymoon Capital
description: Known as the Honeymoon Capital of the world, Niagara Falls is a city known for love, adventure, and thrill. The objects in this exhibit are all examples of love and romance in the  greater Niagara region or have some connection to the Niagara region. Created as part of the VISA 2P90: 19th Century Visual Culture course at Brock University.
subject: Letters; Niagara Falls; Niagara Region
creator: Marley McLean

title: Don't Slip and Niagara Fall!
description: A collection of images displaying the extreme winters of Niagara Falls and how its unique weather conditions create extraordinary natural phenomenons. By comparing images of the same scenery in Niagara Falls through the 19th century alone, we can see how the winter weather conditions can have such large impacts on certain parts of the natural landscape, as well as manmade structures. Created as part of the VISA 2P90: 19th Century Visual Culture course at Brock University.
subject: Niagara Falls; Weather; Niagara Region
creator: Riley Cuddy-Colbon

title: A Fond Sigh of Friendship
description: This collection features imagery and literature found in a 19th century Friendship Album, and a few from the 20th century.  These friendship albums provide insight into the history of Niagara and the types of people that lived there. Created as part of the VISA 2P90: 19th Century Visual Culture course at Brock University.
subject: Friendship albums; Niagara Falls; Niagara Region
creator: Abigail Leeder

title: The Tipped Inkwell
description: This collection provides a look at nineteenth century penmanship and how that relates to the century itself. Created as part of the VISA 2P90: 19th Century Visual Culture course at Brock University.
subject: Penmanship; Niagara Region
creator: Rachel Stangl

title: Niagara in the 19th Century as Seen by George E. Curtis
description: The collection series focuses on the historical viewpoint of the United States' Niagara area, and it is credited to George E. Curtis, who was active from the 1860s until 1910 and was recognized for his stereoscopic views of Niagara Falls. Created as part of the VISA 2P90: 19th Century Visual Culture course at Brock University.
subject: Stereoscopic views; Niagara Falls; Niagara Region
creator: Leyao Chen; Ke Shi; Yufei Wang; Jingyue Zhang

title: Souvenir Art in Niagara Falls
description: This digital exhibit focuses on tourism in Niagara during the late 19th century to mid 20th century, including the writing and souvenir art associated. Most of the artifacts presented were created by locals, advertising tourist attractions, andjournals kept by tourists and newsletters. Included are also poems, letters and photographs. Created as part of the VISA 2P90: 19th Century Visual Culture course at Brock University.
subject: Advertisements; Niagara Falls; Niagara Region; Tourism
creator: Nikki Singh; Sara Fellman; Piper Valdock

title: Letters to St. Catharines
description: This digital exhibition features a collection of handwritten letters from people to or from St. Catharines, Ontario. The grouping of letters displays a wide array of communication including words of love, letters from grandmothers for someone’s first birthday, and land ownership disputes. Created as part of the VISA 2P90: 19th Century Visual Culture course at Brock University.
subject: Letters; Niagara Falls; Niagara Region
creator: Jessie Richard

title: Upper Steel Arch Bridge in Cyanotype
description: The focus of this digital exhibit is a photobook of cyanotype prints of the Upper Steel Arch Bridge, taken by Charles W. Dill, who was the superintendent of the bridge from 1895-1899. The Upper Steel Arch Bridge, also known as “Honeymoon Bridge,” was the fourth bridge spanning the Niagara Gorge. Created as part of the VISA 2P90: 19th Century Visual Culture course at Brock University.
subject: Cyanotype prints; Niagara Falls; Bridges; Niagara Region
creator: Christy Mitchell

title: The Terrapin Tower in 19th Century Niagara
description: This collection of images explores the history of the destroyed 19th century Niagara Falls tourist site, The Terrapin Tower, and displays its impact on visual culture during the time of its existence. Created as part of the VISA 2P90: 19th Century Visual Culture course at Brock University.
subject: Terrapin Tower; Niagara Falls; Niagara Region
creator: Naomi Egbunike

title: Niagara As Told Through Its Advertisements
description: The aim of this digital exhibition is to provide insight into the Niagara region by analyzing the intentions and depictions of companies through their advertisements during the 19th century. Created as part of the VISA 2P90: 19th Century Visual Culture course at Brock University.
subject: Advertisements; Niagara Falls; Niagara Region
creator: Connor Old

title: A Look at Healthcare in the Niagara Region in the Long 19th Century
description: This digital exhibition is a series of images that shows what healthcare looked like in the 19th century around the Niagara Region. Created as part of the VISA 2P90: 19th Century Visual Culture course at Brock University.
subject: Niagara Region; Healthcare
creator: Ella Bos; Morgan Sarah Jane Branton

title: Pandemic Memories
description: A digital collection pertaining to memories of the pandemic at home and at the University at Buffalo. This is an idiosyncratic set of images, documents, and clips to capture elements of the lock down and longer pandemic. The collection hints at the alternative ways of living and working during the initial stages of the pandemic and the gradual return to some kind of near normal. Created as part of CollectionBuilder course at the Digital Humanities Summer Institute (DHSI).
subject: Pandemic; COVID-19
creator: Claire Schen

title: Babylonian Elites
description: This digital collection highlights the social networks of the elites in the city of Babylon during the reign of Darius I (522–486 BCE). Elite families passed down their family archives from generation to generation, some of which are preserved today. These archives consist of texts (contracts and court documents) concerning their properties, including its acquisition, management and transfer (such as inheritance divisions, dowry and gifting). Created as part of the CollectionBuilder course at the Digital Humanities Summer Institute (DHSI).
subject: Babylon; Family archives
creator: Jinyan Wang

title: Gullah Geechee Collection
description: Collection of resources both available virtually and from personal data gathering concerning Gullah Geecheee. The current project seeks to gather contemporary expressions of Gullah Geechee together with historical representations to let visitors experience the language across time and space. Created as part of the CollectionBuilder course at the Digital Humanities Summer Institute (DHSI).
subject: Interviews; Gullah Geecheee; African Americans
creator: Spud McCullough

title: Recusant Readers
description: From the seventeenth through the eighteenth century, the Finch family of Mawdesley, Lancashire collected and left their marks in a library of devotional, homiletic, educational, polemical, and practical works. The Finch-Haydocke collection consists of roughly 250 printed books and several paper-bound manuscript notebooks collected or produced by the Finch family. Created as part of the CollectionBuilder course at the Digital Humanities Summer Institute (DHSI).
subject: Manuscripts; School books
institution: Digital Humanities Summer Institute (DHSI); Stonyhurst College Historic Libraries
creator: Clarissa Chenovick

title: UMW Buildings
description: A demo collection containing photographs of buildings at the University of Mary Washington in Fredericksburg, VA. Created as part of the CollectionBuilder course at the Digital Humanities Summer Institute (DHSI).
subject: University buildings

title: Touring Antiquity: The Richard Stillwell Collection
description: Richard Stillwell (1899-1982), Princeton '21 and '24, was a beloved long-serving member of the faculty and a prolific scholar. More than 1200 photographic negatives taken early in his career belong to the Research Photographs collections of the Department of Art and Archaeology. Beginning in early 2019 Visual Resources staff (with much help from undergraduate student workers), captured, edited, and catalogued the collection. This digitization project has culminated in this online exhibition showcasing the many fine quality images of the collection, most of which were taken in Greece between 1924 and 1934 and many likely taken by his wife at the time, Agnes Newall. Created as part of the CollectionBuilder course at the Digital Humanities Summer Institute (DHSI).
subject: Photographic negatives; Photographs
institution: Digital Humanities Summer Institute (DHSI); Princeton University
creator: Julia Gearhart

title: The Reparative Digital Archive Platform
description: The Reparative Digital Archive Platform reckons with our ever present and already historical moment of dissonance, when a push to return to "normal" is resisted by the ongoing disruptions of mutating disease and racial and economic disparity. Created as part of the CollectionBuilder course at the Digital Humanities Summer Institute (DHSI).
subject: Design thinking; Documentation
institution: Digital Humanities Summer Institute (DHSI); Lincoln Center for Applied Ethics (LCAE); Arizona State University
creator: Liz Grumbach

title: The Morrisseau Project: 1955-1985
description: Why are Morrisseau's pieces so colourful? Who are the figures depicted in his art? How did he combine marketing savviness and the practice of gifting to further his career? Delve into Morrisseau's own words and explorations by researchers through these vignettes. Created as part of the CollectionBuilder course at the Digital Humanities Summer Institute (DHSI).
subject: Art; Indigenous art

title: Africa and Andalusia Demo Collection
description: This is a demo collection using CollectionBuilder-GH based on sites visited by the website creator in 2016. Created as part of the CollectionBuilder course at the Digital Humanities Summer Institute (DHSI).
subject: Africa; Andalusia
creator: Bryon Maxey

title: Thomas Andrews, Shipbuilder
description: An online gallery in honor and memory of Thomas Andrews, designer of the Titanic. Created as part of the CollectionBuilder course at the Digital Humanities Summer Institute (DHSI).
subject: Titanic; Ship building
institution: Digital Humanities Summer Institute (DHSI); University of Alabama
creator: Castiel Lisko

title: Stuff Without Context
description: This demo collection features a random selection of digitized sketches and drawings by the website creator. Created as part of the CollectionBuilder course at the Digital Humanities Summer Institute (DHSI).
subject: Sketches; Drawings
collection_type: Student Project; Digital Exhibit; Personal Collection
creator: Roberto Antonio Munoz Gomez

title: Factory Forms: Making Copies in the Age of Automation
description: This digital collection contains images from the website creator's book-in-progress, Factory Forms. Created as part of the CollectionBuilder course at the Digital Humanities Summer Institute (DHSI).
subject: Art book; Art
creator: Mal Ahern

title: Tlingit Placenames
description: The Taku River Tlingit First Nation is located in Northern BC (Canada). TRTFN traditional territory encompasses an area that expands beyond provincial/territorial and national borders. This website is a sandbox for developing the TRT Language and Land App, a static mobile version of the existing TRTFN GeoLive placenames map. The Language and Land App is a collaborative project with the TRTFN Land Guardians, who "act as the eyes and ears of the TRTFN Lands Department." Created as part of the CollectionBuilder course at the Digital Humanities Summer Institute (DHSI).
subject: Placenames; Indigenous peoples
creator: Emily Comeau

title: The Laura Goodman Salverson Archive
description: Laura Goodman Salverson (1890-1970) was best known for her Norse-inspired fiction and her sympathetic depictions of Scandinavian and German immigrants in North America. This archive is an attempt to recover Salverson’s works and bring her literary contributions back into public view. Created as part of the CollectionBuilder course at the Digital Humanities Summer Institute (DHSI).
subject: Literature; Laura Goodman
creator: Sydney Lines

title: Punk Rock Drum Machine
description: Punk Rock Drum Machine Digital Archive hosts creative output from the artistic entity known as Punk Rock Drum Machine. Created as part of the CollectionBuilder course at the Digital Humanities Summer Institute (DHSI).
subject: Punk rock; Music
creator: Patrick Flanigan

title: Necromancy: A Hauntology of Grief, Materiality, and Research Creation
description: The works of art contained in this digital collection were created for the website creator's Master’s thesis in Communication and Culture. Each work was made by photographing objects of sentimental value with a CIS (Contact Image Sensor) printer scanner. Most objects have been distorted, warped, stretched, and abstracted within the image, a result of the interupption and disruption of the object’s scan by physically manipulating the materials, the scanner itself, or the platen cover as the CIS bar carries out its scan. Created as part of the CollectionBuilder course at the Digital Humanities Summer Institute (DHSI).
subject: Art; Scans
collection_type: Student Project; Digital Exhibit; Digital Scholarship Project
institution: Digital Humanities Summer Institute (DHSI); Toronto Metropolitan University
creator: Griffen Horsley

title: A Robe By Any Other Name
description: This digital exhibit focuses on the Aga Khan Museum’s PS24 Robe and aims to identify its thematic commonalities, possible origins in Central Asia, and broader lessons learned through investigating the artefact in a digital context. Created as part of the CollectionBuilder course at the Digital Humanities Summer Institute (DHSI).
subject: Textiles; Robes
institution: Digital Humanities Summer Institute (DHSI); University of Toronto
creator: Elizabeth Abraham

title: Papers of George Washington Addenda
description: This digital collection contains all newly found documents not included in the print edition of the Papers of George Washington. Created as part of the CollectionBuilder course at the Digital Humanities Summer Institute (DHSI).
subject: George Washington
creator: Nickoal Eichmann-Kalwara

title: Medieval Manuscripts at the Loyola Notre Dame Library
description: This collection showcases manuscripts from the Loyola Notre Dame Library archives. LNDL Medieval Manuscripts includes images of historiated initials, illuminated initials, and full page illustrations from the three medieval manuscripts featured in the library collection. The collection includes a 13th-century Italian quarto from a large Bible featuring Corinthians I and II and part of Galatians, a 15th-century Italian Book of Hours, and a 15th-century French Book of Hours. All three manuscripts were donated to Notre Dame by Father John Fletcher in the 1940s. Created as part of the CollectionBuilder course at the Digital Humanities Summer Institute (DHSI).
subject: Manuscripts; Medieval texts
institution: Digital Humanities Summer Institute (DHSI); Loyola Notre Dame Library
creator: Christina Guerra

title: Potlatch Historical Society Collection
description: This digital collection depicts life in and around Potlatch, Idaho from 1880 to 2022. The collection is comprised of 2,614 photographs and documents from Potlatch and surrounding areas. The digital materials in the Potlatch Historical Society Collection were donated to the University of Idaho Library by the Potlatch Historical Society. Some were also collected via community digitization days held at the Potlatch Public Library in 2017 and 2018.
subject: Local history; Family history; Idaho
institution: University of Idaho; Potlatch Historical Society
creator: University of Idaho Library

title: Fire Lines
description: A multimodal essay using threads from archival material, alongside Indigenous fire knowledge and ideas from Western science, in an effort to understand the lasting effects of 1910’s Great Fire on the landscapes of the Northwest.
subject: Fire; Idaho
collection_type: Student Project; Digital Scholarship Project; Multimodal Essay
creator: TheCDIL, Center for Digital Inquiry and Learning, University of Idaho Library; Isabel Marlens

title: Digital Library of Idaho
description: A collection of digital libraries from across the state of Idaho, providing access points to the varied historical images, documents, and other media available to the public.
subject: Idaho; Digital collections
creator: University of Idaho Library; Boise State University; Idaho State University; Idaho Commission for Libraries

title: Ghana Music and Dance Initiative
description: The Ghana Music and Dance initiative was started as a cooperative effort from ethnomusicologists, digital librarians, and Ghanian music specialists to actively document and preserve the sounds, dances, and traditions of Ghanian music. Liam Marchant, Center for Digital Inquiry and Learning 2021 Undergraduate Fellow, and Professor of ethnomusicology at the University of Idaho, Barry Bilderback, connected with Habib Iddrisu from the Univeristy of Oregon to create an engaging, accessable, and easy-to-update platform for video, photography, and audio recordings collected by the Agoo-Bi Nii Center and other various repositories of Ghanian dance and music.
subject: Ghana; Music; Dance
creator: TheCDIL, Center for Digital Inquiry and Learning, University of Idaho Library; Liam Marchant; Barry Bilderback

title: Wolf Reintroduction
description: This goal of this interactive multimodal project is to show various dimensions surrounding the wolf controversy in Idaho: a coalescence of regional viewpoints and events stemming from the initial release of Canis Lupus in 1995.
subject: Wolves; Idaho
collection_type: Student Project; Digital Scholarship Project; Multimodal Essay
creator: TheCDIL, Center for Digital Inquiry and Learning, University of Idaho Library; Floriana Tulli

title: Black History at the University of Idaho
description: This project is an ongoing collaboration between the Black History Research Lab and the University of Idaho Library that examines the history and contribution of Black students, faculty, staff, and administrators at the University of Idaho. This digital exhibit space seeks to uncover untold histories and highlight the accomplishments of Black individuals on campus.
subject: Black history; Student organizations; African Americans
creator: University of Idaho Library; Sydney Freeman Jr.

title: Early Chinese in Montreal
description: A virtual exhibit of early Chinese residents in Montreal, QC. Montreal's Chinese community first established itself when workers came east after the completion of the railway. By 1888, there were about 30 Chinese men living in Montreal, but by the 1890s, families had also begun to settle in a nascent Chinatown. However, many of them left behind few records. Early Chinese in Montreal is an exhibit that has both a physical and digital component. Both are inspired by original research conducted by graduate students in one of Dr. Mary Chapman’s UBC English graduate seminars. The digital exhibit attempts to provide more longevity, interaction, and access to this original research.
subject: Immigration; Chinese Canadians
creator: Dr. Mary Chapman; Sydney Lines

title: Life in Stereoscope
description: The stereoviews on display in this collection were selected from the University of Texas (UT) School of Information's teaching collection. Each speaks to a different way this technology was used – to travel the globe, understand the labor movement, and view the domestic lives of those photographed. Created as part of the Planning and Understanding Exhibits course at UT.
creator: Sarah Norris; Sam Howard

title: Once, Twice, Trice: Students Tackle Naming Jack Trice Stadium
description: A Special Collections and University Archives exhibition, highlighting the 24 years of student activism to honor Jack Trice and his ideals by naming the football stadium in his honor. Curated by Greg Bailey and Rebecca Wells, Special Collections and University Archives. Web development by Digital Scholarship and Initiatives.
subject: Football; Stadium
creator: Greg Bailey; Rebecca Wells; Olivia Wikle; Iowa State University Library

title: Chinese Graves at Melbourne General Cemetery
description: This website documents the graves of Chinese interred at the Melbourne General Cemetery from 1885 to 2013. The headstone records include name in Chinese characters, location of ancestral village, county, and province in China (in Chinese characters), and birth and death dates.
subject: Chinese; Cemetery records; Australia; Family history
institution: Chinese Australian Family Historians of Victoria
creator: Terry Young; Chinese Australian Family Historians of Victoria

title: Beowulf-s
description: The beowulf-s project presents the content of Chauncey B. Tinker’s The Translations of Beowulf: A Critical Bibliography (1903) as a digital collection to explore the referenced texts along side his introductions, extracts, and criticism.
subject: Texts; Bibliography
creator: Evan Peter Williamson

title: Japanese Patentees in Sweden (1892 - 1938)
description: A hidden transnational history told by patent documents, about Japanese inventors who tried to protect and promote their innovations eight thousand kilometers away.
subject: Patents; Business history; Japan; Sweden; History
creator: Yunting Xie

title: American Women Working in the 20th Century
description: American Women Working in the 20th Century is a digital collection of photos depicting women engaging in various types of work throughout time and space.
subject: Women; Women employees; Home economics; Women and war
creator: jonesa24; Jennleebray; dylanwave; nellienano; ftalebhaghighi

title: American Literature and the Civil Rights Movement
description: This collection includes photographs, documents, and objects that provide context for historical and thematic elements found in popular literature produced during the height of the American Civil Rights Movement.
subject: African Americans; Housing discrimination; Race relations; Civil rights
creator: Grunder; Lucero; Rocha; Wilcox

title: Read My Lips: Queer Protest Art and Ephemera
description: An exploration of queer protest art and ephemera across time and space within the United States.
subject: Art; LGBTQ; Protest
creator: Taylor Doherty; Mak Jones; Jesus Villalobos; Cheyenne Lopex; Violeta Keifer

title: A Visual Postcard of Arizona's Historical Sites
description: This collection highlights the Coronado Trail, San Xavier del Bac Mission, Fort Defiance, and the Grand Canyon.
subject: Coronado Trail; San Xavier del Bac Mission; Fort Defiance; Grand Canyon
creator: M. Aros; R. Chilicky; C.J. Jeanson; L. Sampson

title: Decades of Change: A Study of 1960s and 1970s Visual Culture
description: A collection of images from the 1960s and 1970s. Materials are contained to the culture of the United States and cover topics such as social movements, politics, art, and scientific progress.
subject: Art; Social movements
creator: Kyle Allen; Matt Clemens; Emily De Angelis, Amalia King; Tori Wilcox

title: Diné Ways of Life Image Collection
description: This collection consists digitized images that seeks to document and represent contemporary living experiences (1950s-onward) of Native peoples in the Arizona-Southwestern region.
subject: Indigenous peoples; Diné
creator: Mary Taylor; Andy Diazcadena; Kevin Chavez

title: Traveling to Europe for Seniors
description: An online resource dedicated to senior citizens and retirees who are contemplating and planning to embark on memorable travels across Europe. This collection offers a variety of guidebooks, ebooks, memoirs, and other resources that can help mature travelers by offering a wealth of information to ensure a safe, enriching, an enjoyable experience.
subject: Senior citizens; Travel; Europe
creator: cll028; nclumbee; donnascott1972

title: Diverse Children's Books
description: A collection of books that showcase different cultures, experiences, and abilities. This collection is built for use with elementary students, and is a great resource to find high interest, up to date books that will help reach all students.
subject: Diversity; Children's books
creator: Amber Fulcher; Sarah Williams

title: Global Fairy Tales: A Collection of Stories from Around the Globe
description: This collection has gathered fables and fairy tales from one side of the globe to the other.
subject: Fairy tales; Stories
creator: Naomi Spicer; Emily Rose Neuberger; Dayna Hodge Lynch

title: Young Adult Fiction: A Collection of Recent Works
description: This collection includes 10 items of current Young Adult Fiction with themes including Coming of Age, Racism, etc. The primary age-group is high school.
subject: Fiction; Coming of age
creator: DJE228; SigiKK

title: Coloring Book Collection
description: This small coloring book collection is for anyone wanting to learn something new and meditate, but that struggles to learn from a book only.
subject: Coloring books; Meditation
creator: WLeehr08; aalle119

title: Bread Making: Resources for Making Bread
description: This collection includes resources covering easy breads and beginner techniques for kids and novice bakers, advanced techniques for professionals or proficient bakers, information on various baking ingredients, and equipment necessary to pursue the hobby.
subject: Bread; Bread making; Baking
creator: jwesthaf

title: A Collection of Romantic Poetry
description: A collection of books on romantic poetry focused on people interested learning about poetry or for people wanting to write poetry
subject: Poetry; Romantic poetry
creator: Andrew Daniels; Alex Zakel

title: Pine Street School and Meridian Elementary
description: This collection contains photos and documents pertaining to the history and historical renovation of the Pine Street School, as well as some materials from the nearby, and institutionally connected, Meridian Elementary School.
subject: Local history; Idaho; Schools
creator: Meridian Library District History Center

title: Philippine Food History
description: Philippine food and beverage have a fascinating and ongoing story reaching into prehistory. This digital collection celebrates how Filipinos have been creatively selecting preferred ingredients, technologies, procedures, and flavors amidst transitioning social, religious, political, economic, and scientific conditions.
subject: Cuisine; Philippines; Food history
creator: Felice Prudente Sta. Maria; Paul Jason Perez

title: Davies Collection: American Libraries Before 1876
description: The Davies Project was an effort to increase knowledge about American university libraries and their collections, begun by Princeton University President emeritus and Professor of Economics and Public Affairs Harold T. Shapiro and Stephen Ferguson, Curator of Rare Books at the Princeton University Library in 2000.
subject: Libraries; Library collections
creator: Harold T. Shapiro; Stephen Ferguson; cwulfman; Princeton University Library

title: Novy Family Recipe Collection
description: This is a collection of family recipe cards created in the mid 1900s and passed down through the Novy family. Created as a final project for Digital Libraries ILS-Z 652 at Indiana University.
subject: Family history; Recipes
creator: Hallie Schmucker

title: Renaissance Art Collection
description: This catalog houses Italian Renaissance art by painters from the Venetian school, collected by the Photo Archive of the Berenson Library at Harvard’s Villa I Tatti. Created for the INFO 663 Metadata Design course at the Pratt Institute.
subject: Renaissance; Art; Venetian school
creator: scosner; lcobos789

title: Hemispheric Institute Digital Video Library
description: This is a collection of streaming videos from the Hemispheric Institute of Performance & Politics. Created for the INFO 663 Metadata Design course at the Pratt Institute.
subject: Performance art; Theatre
creator: Beth Grassmann; Patrick Kingchatchaval; Samie Konet

title: Voices from the Food Revolution
description: Metadata Application Profile for oral histories created by Steve Beck, Alyse Delaney, and Candace Hernandez. Created for the INFO 663 Metadata Design course at the Pratt Institute.
subject: Interviews; Food revolution; Food writing; Cuisine
creator: Steve Beck; Alyse Delaney; Candace Hernandez

title: Calabash: A Journal of Caribbean Arts and Letters
description: Calabash: A Journal of Caribbean Arts and Letters was an international literary journal dedicated to publishing works encompassing, but not limited to, the Anglophone, Francophone, Hispanophone and Dutch-speaking Caribbean. Created for the INFO 663 Metadata Design course at the Pratt Institute.
subject: Literary journal; Caribbean; Poetry
creator: Eleanor Morgan; Brina Diaz; Delali Ayivor

title: Electronic Theses & Dissertations
description: This is a digital archive of Electronic Theses and Dissertations. Created for the INFO 663 Metadata Design course at the Pratt Institute.
subject: Theses; Dissertations
creator: holeofficial; dazzlepansy

title: MUSEO-GIF
description: Este es el resultado del ejercicio de digitalizar, coleccionar y reinterpretar piezas del Museo de la Independencia - Casa del Florero en Bogotá. Este proyecto hace parte de los ejercicios realizados por estudiantes del curso Cultura Digital de la Línea de Humanidades Digitales en la Pontificia Universidad Javeriana.
subject: GIFs; Art
creator: Cultura Digital, Pontificia Universidad Javeriana

title: A Latino Children's Book Collection
description: The Piñata Books Collection features books published for children in Spanish, English and four in Nahuat. Piñata Books is an imprint of Arte Público Press, the premier publisher of books written by Latinos in the United States.
subject: Children's books; Hispanic books
creator: Gabriela Baeza Ventura; Ana P. Sánchez

title: Celebration of Faculty Scholarship 2024
description: A digital collection of publications by Loyola University Chicago faculty presented by Loyola University Chicago Libraries
subject: Faculty scholarship; Academic publications
creator: Felix Oke; Loyola University Chicago

title: AI and Libraries Database
description: Database of resources generated by the LJA Course AI and Libraries, For Skeptics.
subject: Artificial Intelligence; AI resources
creator: Tim Ribaric

title: Mapping Thonet
description: Mapping Thonet is the new visual processing of the image research "The Public Image of Thonet, Photographs 1850-1900." The project was funded by the NEUSTART KULTUR project fund and VG Bild-Kunst in 2021.
subject: Art; Photography
creator: Sarah Kindermann
